user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_connection_values:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int
MHD_get_connection_values (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                           enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                           MHD_KeyValueIterator iterator,
                           void *iterator_cls)
{
  int ret;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return -1;
  ret = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    if (0 != (pos->kind & kind))
    {
      ret++;
      if ( (NULL != iterator) &&
           (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->value)) )
        return ret;
    }
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pos->header
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment pos->header is used only for reading (passed into the iterator as a header name/value). If the struct member is declared as a non-const pointer (e.g. char *header) then Rule 8.13 is violated because the pointer should point to const-qualified data when it is not modified. A specific violation scenario: struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header { char *header; char *value; ... }; header/value are never modified but are passed as read-only parameters to the iterator — they should be declared const char *header; const char *value;.
